awd_titl_txt: RAPID: The effects of extreme drought on sediment transport and deposition in water-supply reservoirs
awd_abstract_narration:
The southwestern U.S. is experiencing an extreme drought that is reducing flow in river systems and producing record low levels in water-supply reservoirs. For example, the Elephant Butte Reservoir on the Rio Grande River in New Mexico was only 5.6% full as of October, exposing a large wedge of sediment that has extended an additional 1 km into the reservoir during the summer of 2021. During the drought, flash floods are the principal means by which water enters the reservoir. Flash floods bring sediment-laden flows that can accumulate in the reservoir and reduce the capacity further. This project will collect time-sensitive data to assess impacts of the extreme drought on water budgets, river sediment transport, and reservoir sedimentation.   The project will train one graduate student in the integration of field, laboratory methods, and numerical modeling. The research has applications to similar processes occurring in coastal regions and will help in making complex decisions on water release and management of wetlands in western river corridors. 

The severe drought in the Rio Grande River basin has caused a delta to emerge at the entrance into the Elephant Butte Reservoir. During the drought year of 2021, spring snowmelt was subdued, and flash floods from storm events became the predominant mechanism for sediment transport into the reservoir. These flash flood-derived sediments accumulate upon entering reservoirs to form a lacustrine delta, which unlike marine deltas, typically experience hyperpycnal flows. Initial research during a monsoon-driven flash flood in July 2021 indicate that heightened sediment and organic carbon transport affected the geomorphology and ecology during the event. This RAPID project will identify the mechanisms driving flash flood sediment transport and morphodynamics in arid fluvio-deltaic systems and determine how extreme drought amplifies these processes. The research will also numerically model the Elephant Butte Reservoir deltaic system to evaluate geomorphic changes in the subaqueous delta driven by highly sediment-laden flash floods, which will also inform the carbon sequestration potential of such rapidly prograding deltas. The proposed research involves two field campaigns in the winter and spring of 2022 to collect water and bed material samples, channel geometry, velocity, and water level measurements, images of the delta front, and casts of a conductivity, temperature, and depth sensor. The data will be incorporated into the hydrodynamics and sediment transport model Delft3D to simulate sediment transport and deposition processes during a flash flood at high resolution, which has never been done in a reservoir setting.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Title: RAPID: The effects of extreme drought on sediment transport and deposition in water-supply reservoirs

In 2021, the US West faced an extreme drought, with 95% of the US West being affected. This led to deltas emerging at the upstream end of water-supply reservoirs across the nation due to historically low water levels. Despite overall low precipitation, occasional flash floods from the seasonal southwest monsoon still impacted reservoirs.

This project aimed to understand the relative role of monsoon-driven flash floods in the Rio Grande Basin, with focus on its major dam; Elephant Butte Reservoir in New Mexico. We hypothesized flashfloods have a disproportional impact during droughts, because of rapid floodplain sedimentation and relatively efficient sediment delivery to the deeper parts of Elephant Butte Reservoir by high-density flows. Sediment delivery to the deeper part of the reservoir is problematic because it reduces longterm water storage capacity.

Over 2021-2022, we repeatedly sampled the Rio Grande during flashfloods, during low-flow winter season, and during snowmelt season. We collected data on the amount and dynamics of water flow throughout the delta, on fine suspended sediment and coarse bedload sediment being transported and deposited.

Analysis of the long-term hydrological station data (USGS at San Marcial, NM) corroborated that snowmelt contributions have been severely limited due to persistent drought conditions over the last decade. This pattern shifts the balance of sediment delivery to larger role for flashfloods.

Our repeat sampling of the Rio Grande at Elephant Butte Reservoir showed that highest river sediment load occurs during flashfloods. Samples indicate that the concentrations in the delta channels are high during all high flow conditions; the Rio Grande water is very turbid. Our observations in the reservoir showed that delivery of flashflood sediment to the subaqueous delta is through plunging flows, an efficient way of delivering sediment to the deeper part of the reservoir.

The project also found that organic carbon concentrations are higher during flashfloods. Our field observations during the July 2021 flashflood indicated large amounts of floating organic matter and even woody debris, possibly due to flushing of accumulated leaf litter from desert gullies. Since this material is delivered to the bottom of the reservoir, it is essentially buried underwater and sequestered. With 100’s of reservoir in the US West possibly behaving in this way, this carbon storage has interesting implications for the regional carbon cycle.

The project collaborated and shared data and study results with water management scientists of the US Bureau of Reclamation. Findings have been presented and the collaboration is leading to additional modeling and assessment of reservoir capacity changes in the US West.
